newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper called to open slightly higher.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper called to open slightly higher.

text.p: COMEX copper futures were called to open slightly higher Friday in line with LME copper prices after a further 1,350 drawdown in LME warehouse copper stocks to 152,475 tonnes.
COMEX copper stocks rose 780 short tons to 46,388 short tons Thursday.
COMEX May copper was called unchanged to up 0.3 cent from Thursday's settlement of 105.55 cents a lb after trading at 106.25 in overnight ACCESS trade.
Support is seen around 104.00 cents still, with resistance around 108.00 in the near term for May delivery.

But daily momentum oscillators remain weak for COMEX May copper, and the contract's five day moving average remains below its 21-day average and its 55-day average, after the contract retreated from eight-month highs seen in March.
The COMEX May/July spread eased back further Thursday to around 1.00 cents, after easing from around 3.5 cents in March, as tightness in the prompt market has eased.

Copper consumption is forecast to grow in all major economies this year, with growth forecasts revised up to 4.4 percent in 1997 and 4.6 percent in 1998, according to a report Friday from the Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU).
But prices are still seen easing as the supply of refined copper is also seen rising faster than first estimated, leading to a build in stocks.
Global stocks rose by an estimated 25,000 tonnes in 1996, with western stocks falling by about 150,000 tonnes but stocks elsewhere rising by 175,000 tonnes.
The EIU forecast a 1997/98 stock build of 375,000 tonnes.
